subject: PSY
title: Introduction to Psychology
description: Introduction to methods and findings of contemporary psychology. Emphasis on psychological basis for understanding human behavior. Consideration of maturation, learning, thinking, motivation, emotion, sensation, perception, and personality. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Course Attributes: Gen Ed-Soc/Behavioral Sciences Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 1030 General Requirements: ( Course or Test: ENGL 1010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. ) or ( Course or Test: DSPR 0800 Minimum Grade of C May not be taken concurrently. ) or ( DSPR 4 May not be taken concurrently. ) or ( A03 19 to 36 May not be taken concurrently. ) or ( S03 710 to 800 May not be taken concurrently. )

subject: PSY
title: Psychology of Adjustment
description: Behavior and adjustment in modern society, maturing self-concept, adjustment to psychological stress, and prevention of maladjustment. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Life Span Devlopmnt Psychology
description: Developmental aspects of psychological functioning from the prenatal period to adulthood with emphasis on individual differences. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Educational Psychology
description: 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Problem Solving
description: Introduction to concepts and methods used in problem-solving. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Stats & Experimental Design
description: Prerequisites: PSY 1030, 3 additional PSY credit hours, a grade of B or higher in MATH1130 or MATH1530; 45 hours of completed course work and be a psychology major. Corequisite: PSY 3020. Fundamental statistics for the behavioral sciences, descriptive uses, probability, one-way, factorial designs, repeated measures and split-plot designs, bivariate correlation and regression, and non-parametrics. 0.000 OR 3.000 Credit hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lecture hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lab hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Laboratory, Lecture All Sections for this Course Counseling and Psychology Department Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Majors: Psychology Must be enrolled in one of the following Classifications: Sophomore Senior Junior Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 3010 General Requirements: ( Course or Test: PSY 1030 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. ) and ( Course or Test: MATH 1130 Minimum Grade of B May not be taken concurrently. ) or ( Course or Test: MATH 1530 Minimum Grade of B May not be taken concurrently. ) and ( Course or Test: PSY 3020 Minimum Grade of D May be taken concurrently. )

subject: PSY
title: Info Literacy in Psychology
description: Prerequisites: PSY 2010 and 3 additional PSY credits. The course emphasizes information literacy in reading, evaluating, and summarizing scientific literature in psychology. The course includes exposure to scientific writing (APA format) and basic research concepts and terminology in psychology. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Course Attributes: Undergraduate Research 1 Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 3020 General Requirements: ( Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. )

subject: PSY
title: Careers in Psychology
description: The course explores the various career paths that can be taken with a degree in psychology, which may include clinical/counseling, cognitive neuroscience, industrial/organizational, healthcare informatics, education research, and other career applications. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Positive Psy:Sci of Well-Being
description: The purpose of this course is to examine the fundamentals of positive psychology. Example topics discussed: happiness, courage, optimism, empathy. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Classifications: Senior Junior

subject: PSY
title: Parapsychology
description: Prerequisite: PSY 1030 with a grade of C or better. An examination of unusual experiences such as ESP, precognition, psychokinesis, ghosts and other paranormal events and the ways these phenomena are investigated by psychologists including the methodological errors that an affect the research. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Experimental Psychology
description: Prerequisite: Minimum grade of C in PSY 3010. Methods and techniques of research in general experimental psychology. Emphasis on design, data collection, analysis, and report writing. 0.000 OR 4.000 Credit hours 0.000 OR 3.000 Lecture hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lab hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Laboratory, Lecture All Sections for this Course Counseling and Psychology Department Course Attributes: Undergraduate Research 1 Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 3110 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 3010 Minimum Grade of C May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Sensation and Perception
description: 0.000 OR 3.000 Credit hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lecture hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lab hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Laboratory, Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Experimental Social Psy
description: Prerequisite: PSY 3110 or consent of instructor. Experimental testing of theories and models, experimental social designs and problems, and assigned and original laboratory projects. 0.000 OR 3.000 Credit hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lecture hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lab hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Laboratory, Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Course Attributes: Undergraduate Research 1 Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 3140 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 3110 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Cognitive Psychology
description: Prerequisite: PSY 2010. Experimental methods used in the study of memory, thinking and cognition. 0.000 OR 3.000 Credit hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lecture hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lab hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Laboratory, Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Course Attributes: Undergraduate Research 2 Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 3150 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Applied Research Methods
description: Prerequisite: PSY 3010. Examination of methods used to research psychological questions of an applied nature in specialties such as industrial, health, consumer, and community psychology. Topics include survey, evaluation, and quasi-experimental research methods. 0.000 OR 3.000 Credit hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lecture hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lab hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Laboratory, Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Course Attributes: Undergraduate Research 1 Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 3160 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 3010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Intro to Social Psychology
description: Prerequisite: PSY 2010. Introduction to methods in social psychology and processes of social influence. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 3300 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Industrial Psychology
description: Introduction to the areas of employee selection, training, performance appraisal, theories, work motivation, and development. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Group Dynamics
description: Group development, the individual in group processes, interaction, leadership, and decision-making. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Psychology of Personality
description: 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture TN eCampus Degree Program Department Restrictions: May not be assigned to one of the following Cohorts: International Cohort

subject: PSY
title: Learning and Cognition
description: Prerequisite: PSY 2010 and a grade of C or higher in PSY 3010. . Theory, research and applications in human learning, and memory and cognitive processes. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4050 General Requirements: ( Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. and Course or Test: PSY 3010 Minimum Grade of C May not be taken concurrently. )

subject: PSY
title: Child Psychology
description: Prerequisite: PSY 2010 and PSY 2130. Hereditary and environmental influence on physical and psychological growth. Cognitive, affective and language development of infant and child with an emphasis on disorders and problems in development. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4100 General Requirements: ( Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. and Course or Test: PSY 2130 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. )

subject: PSY
title: Brain and Behavior
description: Prerequisites: PSY 2010 and 3 additional PSY credits. Biological approach to understanding behavior. Students will focus on the anatomy and physiology of the nervous system in reference to behavior, perception, mental disorders, and drug action. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4130 General Requirements:

subject: PSY
title: Health Psychology
description: Prerequisite: PSY 3110 or consent of instructor. Biopsychosocial approach to examining how stress, personality, and lifestyle are related to physical health. Students will experientially explore a variety of coping strategies and relaxation techniques geared toward self-assessment and understanding. Student enrolled in the 5000-level course will be required to complete additional work as stated in the syllabus. 0.000 OR 3.000 Credit hours 0.000 OR 2.000 Lecture hours 0.000 OR 1.000 Lab hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Laboratory, Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4140 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 3110 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Psychology of Personality
description: Application of psychological principles to an understanding of personality, development, and interpersonal adjustments. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4150 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Abnormal Psychology
description: Prerequisites: PSY 2010 and 3 additional PSY credits. Nature of abnormal behavior, etiology, symptomatology and treatment. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4160 General Requirements: ( Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. and Rule: PSY RULE: PSY 2010 + 3 addl PSY credits for a total of 1 conditions for a total of 3 credits ) and ( PSY 1000 to 2099 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. ) and ( PSY 2011 to 4999 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. ) End of rule PSY RULE

subject: PSY
title: Adolescent Psychology
description: Origin and principles of behavior with emphasis on educational problems in guiding growth and development of adolescents. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4200 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Intro to Psychological Testing
description: Basic concepts in psychological testing, interpreting test scores, and types of standardized tests. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4250 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Adult Psychology
description: Physical, cognitive, and psychological development in young adulthood, middle age, and old age. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4300 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Intro-Therapeutic Techq
description: Prerequisite: PSY 4150 or 4160 or consent of instructor. An introduction to various therapeutic techniques including analytic, nondirective, and broadly based behavioral approaches. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4320 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 4150 to 4160 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Psychopharmacology
description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Drugs: the interaction between psychological and physiological effects on behavior. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Restrictions: May not be enrolled as the following Classifications: Sophomore Undergraduate Special Freshman Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4400 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Data Analytics in Psy
description: Prerequisite: PSY 3010 and PSY 3110 with a B or better. Advanced topics in data analysis, graphing, and interpretation of psychological measures. 0.000 OR 3.000 Credit hours 0.000 OR 1.000 Lecture hours 0.000 OR 4.000 Lab hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Laboratory, Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4600 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 3010 Minimum Grade of B May not be taken concurrently. and Course or Test: PSY 3110 Minimum Grade of B May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: History of Psychology
description: Prerequisite: PSY 2010. Theoretical systems, experiments, and personalities in the development of modern psychology. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4800 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 2010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Concepts of Gerontology
description: Prerequisites: PSY 3200 or 3300 or SOC 1010. Physical and psychosocial aging processes. Issues in the care of the senior adult. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4810 General Requirements: ( Course or Test: PSY 3200 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. ) or ( Course or Test: PSY 3300 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. ) or ( Course or Test: SOC 1010 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently. )

subject: PSY
title: Special Topics
description: Prerequisite: Junior standing or consent of instructor. Concentration on a special topic in psychology. Course may be repeated if topic is different. Students enrolled in the 5000-level course will be required to complete additional work as stated in the syllabus. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Independent Study, Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Restrictions: May not be enrolled as the following Classifications: Sophomore Undergraduate Special Freshman

subject: PSY
title: Special Topics
description: Prerequisite: Junior standing or consent of instructor. Concentration on a special topic in psychology. Course may be repeated if topic is different. Students enrolled in the 5000-level course will be required to complete additional work as stated in the syllabus. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department Restrictions: May not be enrolled as the following Classifications: Sophomore Undergraduate Special Freshman

subject: PSY
title: Special Topics
description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor. Concentration on a special topic in psychology. 1.000 Credit hours 3.000 Other hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Independent Study Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Special Topics
description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor. Concentration on a special topic in psychology. 2.000 Credit hours 2.000 Other hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Independent Study Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Special Topics
description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor. Concentration on a special topic in psychology. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Lecture hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Lecture Counseling and Psychology Department

subject: PSY
title: Senior Thesis
description: Prerequisite: Minimum grade of C in PSY 3010 and PSY 3110 and consent of instructor. Capstone experience that requires students to conduct an original research project, which ties together previously learned statistical methods, research skills, and oral/written communication skills. Students complete all work through the presentation of the research proposal. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Other hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Seminar Counseling and Psychology Department Course Attributes: Undergraduate Research 3 Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4930 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 3110 Minimum Grade of C May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Senior Thesis
description: Prerequisite: PSY 4930 and consent of instructor. Capstone experience that requires students to conduct an original research project, which ties together previously learned statistical methods, research skills, and oral/written communication skills. Students complete the data collection, statistical analysis, and final write-up. 3.000 Credit hours 3.000 Other hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Seminar Counseling and Psychology Department Course Attributes: Undergraduate Research 3 Prerequisites: Prereq for PSY 4931 General Requirements: Course or Test: PSY 4930 Minimum Grade of D May not be taken concurrently.

subject: PSY
title: Field Experience in Psychology
description: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor. Supervised application of psychology in educational, therapeutic, or commercial institutions. Student is required to identify the location, establish an agreement with an individual willing to supervise the experience from the location and complete all necessary documentation from faculty instructor of record. May be repeated up to 6 credit hours as long as each practicum assignment is substantially different. 1.000 TO 3.000 Credit hours 1.000 TO 3.000 Other hours Levels: Undergraduate Schedule Types: Practicum/Co-op Counseling and Psychology Department Course Attributes: Service Learning 1, Service Learning 2, Service Learning 3, Undergraduate Research 1, Undergraduate Research 2, Undergraduate Research 3 Restrictions: May not be enrolled as the following Classifications: Sophomore Undergraduate Special Freshman
